Context:
The George Brown College acknowledges systemic racism and promotes fairness, equity, accountability, and transparency through the Office of Anti-Racism, Equity and Human Rights Services (OAREHRS). The OAREHRS manages human rights complaints, advises on diversity and inclusion, and is responsible for matters under the following policies and legislations:

1. Human Rights Discrimination and Harassment Policy
2. Sexual Assault and Sexual Violence Policy and Protocol
3. AODA Accessibility Policy
4. Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act

The OAREHRS can be contacted at diversity@georgebrown.ca or 416-415-5000 Ext. 3668 for further inquiries. All services are confidential. The Diversity Calendar is available online and in print for cultural observances. TTY: 1-877-515-5559.

The OAREHRS condemns incidents of gender-based and transphobic violence, including the stabbing incident at the University of Waterloo on June 28, 2023. The Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA) became law in 2005. The college has campaigns, resources, and Human Rights Advisors to help individuals. Information about disclosing and reporting sexual violence, policies, emergency contacts, and support can be found online. The college also supports the 2SLGBTQIA+ community.

Collecting race-based data is not mentioned in the text.
file_path: scraped_pages/otherpages/Office of Anti-Racism, Equity and Human Rights Services | George Brown College.txt

Context:
* George Brown College has a Office of Anti-Racism, Equity and Human Rights Services (OAREHRS) led by AVP Jennifer Grant.
* Jennifer Grant oversees equity and inclusion efforts, human rights and sexual violence prevention and support initiatives, and ensures the college complies with Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA) and privacy protection laws.
* She is an alumna of the Child and Youth Care program at the School of Social and Community Services at George Brown.
* Prior to becoming OAREHRS Director, she taught and mentored students in the same program for 14 years.
* Jennifer has experience working with youth justice, children's mental health, and child advocacy.
* She has led initiatives to advance anti-racist and anti-oppressive practices in not-for-profit and governmental environments.
* Jennifer worked as a child and youth worker and social service caseworker before moving into management roles such as Manager, Program Development and Implementation with Central Toronto Youth Services and Manager, Advocacy Services with the Provincial Advocate for Children and Youth.
* George Brown College's campuses are located at Casa Loma Campus: 160 Kendal Ave., Room C221, St. James Campus: 200 King St. E., Room 264D, and Waterfront Campus: 51 Dockside Dr., Room 230.
* The college acknowledges that it is located on the traditional territory of the Mississaugas of New Credit and the land of other Indigenous Peoples.
* Contact information for diversity inquiries: diversity@georgebrown.ca or 416-415-5000 Ext. 3668, TTY: 1-877-515-5559.
file_path: scraped_pages/otherpages/Office of Anti-Racism, Equity and Human Rights Services | George Brown College.txt

Context: Jennifer is an alumna of George Brown College where she earned a diploma in Child and Youth Work. She also holds a Bachelor of Arts degree in Psychology from McMaster University and a Master of Education in Adult Education and Community Development from the University of Toronto (OISE). Jennifer has experience providing coaching, mentoring, training, and consulting services to community organizations, their leadership teams, and boards in areas of anti-oppressive and anti-racist change. The contact information for George Brown College is 416-415-2000 (voice) and 1-877-515-5559 (TTY), with the email address ask.george@georgebrown.ca, and social media hub available for more information. The website content is subject to change without notice and should not be considered as a representation, offer, or warranty. Students are advised to verify George Brown College fee requirements.
